metadata.case_name: Income Tax Authorities v. Assessee (Hindu Undivided Family)

facts.text: The assessee is a Hindu Undivided Family.

For assessment year 1947-48, assessment made by Income Tax Officer, District 1(2) on February 12, 1952, holding income of Rs. 1,41,851/- from forests in East Pakistan as non-agricultural income taxable under Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.
Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who by order dated February 7, 1956 held the amount as agricultural income exempt from tax.
Department appealed to Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, appeal filed by Income Tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta.
Assessee formerly resided at 24/25 Beadon Row, Calcutta, shifted in 1954 to 29B, Ballygunge Circular Road, Calcutta, bringing him within jurisdiction of Income Tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta.
Preliminary objection before Tribunal by assessee: appeal incompetent as filed by ITO District VI, not by ITO District 1(2) who made assessment.
Tribunal rejected objection, held jurisdiction vested in ITO District VI under section 64(2) due to change of residence.
No mention in statement of case or Tribunal reasoning of any order of transfer by Commissioner or Board of Revenue transferring files from ITO District 1(2) to District VI.
No mention of which Commissioner directed ITO District VI to file appeal.
High Court answered reference against Revenue: appeal before Tribunal not filed by proper person.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the appeal before the Appellate Tribunal was filed by a proper person?

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in considering facts not in statement of case, such as subordination of officers to different Commissioners and absence of transfer orders; exceeded jurisdiction under s.66 and should have called for supplementary statement.
ITO District VI had jurisdiction under s.64(2) due to assessee's change of residence in 1954, making him proper person to file appeal under direction of Commissioner per s.33(2).

respondent_arguments.text: Original assessment by ITO District 1(2), subordinate to Commissioner of Income Tax, Calcutta; ITO District VI subordinate to Commissioner of West Bengal; no transfer by Board under s.57A, so District 1(2) remained in seisin.
Change of residence while appeal to AAC pending did not transfer case/file to District VI; original assessing officer retains jurisdiction to complete case including appeals.

court_reasoning.text: Ignore facts found by High Court not in statement of case; answer depends on interpretation of s.33(2) read with s.64(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court exceeded jurisdiction under s.66.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.33(2), Commissioner directs 'the Income Tax Officer' to appeal; denotes ITO having jurisdiction/concern with assessee; ministerial act by ITO.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Commissioner cannot direct any ITO, but one concerned with assessee.

court_reasoning.text: By 1954 shift, ITO District VI had jurisdiction over assessee per s.64(2); thus proper to file appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: ITO with current residential jurisdiction concerned with appeal.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent from Punjab HC in R.B.L. Benarsi Dass; any ITO cannot file; must have concern; follows Calcutta HC in S. Sarkar Co.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Concurrent jurisdiction possible; no transfer needed for jurisdiction-based authority.

holdings.text: The Income Tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta, having jurisdiction over the assessee under s.64(2), was a proper person to file the appeal to the Tribunal under direction of Commissioner per s.33(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. S. Sarkar Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: 'The' ITO means one concerned with the case.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: ITO of residence jurisdiction can initiate proceedings on prior assessment.

precedents_cited.case_name: R. B. L. Benarsi Dass v. C.I.T., East Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Incorrect that any ITO can be directed; must be concerned ITO.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income Tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs jurisdiction for assessment, appeals to Tribunal, transfers; s.33(2) requires direction to 'the ITO' with concern/jurisdiction.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, held that the appeal to Tribunal was filed by proper person (ITO District VI with jurisdiction), answering reference in favor of Revenue.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment reversed.

key_quotes.text: 'The' Income Tax Officer... denotes an Income Tax Officer having jurisdiction over the assessee or the matter.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The Income Tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta, was concerned with the appeal filed on the direction of the Commissioner of Income Tax.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The representative of the assessee conceded that the assessee... shifted to 29/B Ballygunge Circular Road... within the jurisdiction of the Income-tax Officer, District VI.
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
